title: How to Eat out Cheap

steps.headline: Sign up for birthday clubs.
steps.description: Many restaurants, especially family restaurants, offer special deals to customers during their birthdays, as long as they sign their names to the appropriate mailing list. Offerings can range from a free dessert to a $30 gift certificate good toward your total purchase.

steps.headline: Ask about a frequent diner card.
steps.description: Some restaurants offer punch cards for patrons who dine at their establishment frequently. After eating at a restaurant often enough and acquiring a certain number of punches in your card, you can often receive a discount or a free meal.

steps.headline: Look for restaurants with a "Kids Eat Free" night.
steps.description: You can find out about these nights by signing up for restaurant e-mail newsletters, or by doing an Internet search on "Kids Eat Free."

steps.headline: Check for "trial nights."
steps.description: Before a new restaurant opens, it may have a trial night to allow its staff to practice. The selection may be reduced, and the service may be slow, but many restaurants serve trademark dishes for free during these trial nights.

steps.headline: Get cash back.
steps.description: Pay for your meal with a cash rewards card, or go to a restaurant that participates in a cash back program.

steps.headline: Stock up on discounted gift cards.
steps.description: On occasion, restaurants may offer a discount on the purchase of gift cards, especially during busy shopping seasons. For instance, around Christmas, you may be able to score $50 worth of gift cards for only $40.

steps.headline: Join a savings club.
steps.description: Many online savings clubs offer deals to local restaurants in the form of coupons and discounted certificates. You may have to register with the website before gaining access to these deals, but in many cases, registration is free.

steps.headline: Join online communities that talk about food.
steps.description: Look for message boards and e-mail newsletters run by foodies, especially those tailored to individuals in your area. They may be able to offer advice on where and how to eat for a discounted price.

steps.headline: Comb through your junk mail and newspaper for coupons.
steps.description: Many restaurants send out coupons via the mail or through inserts tucked into your local paper. It may take a little time to sort the deals from the junk, but the extra effort can really pay off.

steps.headline: Check the restaurant website for coupons.
steps.description: Some restaurants may offer a free printable coupon or coupon code when you visit, especially if you sign up for a free e-newsletter through their website.

steps.headline: Make use of social media.
steps.description: Some restaurants offer freebies to "fans" and "followers" off their social media accounts.

steps.headline: Ask restaurants about their "corkage" fee.
steps.description: Some restaurants will allow you to bring in your own alcohol, and will only charge you a small fee to have the waiter serve it. Many restaurants mark up a bottle of wine by 300 to 400 percent, however, making the fee you would pay to bring your own wine considerably cheaper than what you might pay for a glass of theirs.

steps.headline: Skip the alcohol altogether.
steps.description: Many restaurants make a large portion of the profits through alcohol sales, and one cocktail could cost you almost as much as one entrée. Skipping the alcohol will trim a large portion from your bill.

steps.headline: Drink water.
steps.description: Soda and other non-alcoholic drinks may seem fairly cheap on their own, but the price can add up quickly. Most restaurants do not charge for tap water, however.

steps.headline: Split a dish.
steps.description: If the restaurant you go to serves notably large dishes, as many do nowadays, order one dish for two people.

steps.headline: Ask about half-size portions.
steps.description: Many restaurants include half portions on their menu, but some restaurants may be willing to prepare a half portion for half the price even if they do not list the offering on the menu.

steps.headline: Buy off the kid's menu.
steps.description: Many sit-down restaurants may place age restrictions on the kid's menu, but some do not, and most fast food joints allow you to order a kid's meal at any age. The kid's menu usually serves smaller portions and offers less selection, but the discounted price may well be worth it.

steps.headline: Eat dessert elsewhere.
steps.description: Restaurant desserts are often pricey, but you can stop by an ice cream stand on your way back for a sweet treat at a significantly cheaper price. Eating dessert at home, whether store-bought or homemade, will save you the most.

steps.headline: Split a dessert.
steps.description: Even restaurants that do not allow you to split meals will usually allow you to share a dessert. This way, you can try a luxurious option off the dessert menu for a fraction of the price.

steps.headline: Eat before you go out.
steps.description: Eating a small snack before dinner may "ruin your appetite," but it will also save you money in the long run. The less hungry you are, the less likely you are to experience "eyes bigger than your stomach" syndrome. Instead of ordering too much food, you can order just the right amount.

steps.headline: Take the meal to go.
steps.description: Ordering for pick-up saves you the price of a drink, and you can get away with leaving a smaller tip (usually 5 to 10%, as opposed to 20%).

steps.headline: Eat early or late.
steps.description: Prices are usually their highest at dinner. Many restaurants offer lower prices during breakfast and lunch, and a few others offer lower prices just before closing. Dine out during a time of day when you know a restaurant's prices are at their lowest.
